title: WeakMultiLabels or MajorityVoter function not working as expected

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
**Describe the bug**
WeakMultiLabels("test_weak_label") is apparently reading the dataset from Argilla running on my machine, but MajorityVoter function is not getting any dataset.  As a result, the classifier program is not getting formed.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. I used the dataset as in attached excel-file: weak_test_classifier.
2. Create a json-load file out of the data in the excel-file using: create_load_file.py.
3. Upload the json-load file into a argilla dataset, named: test_weak_label, using: create_rubrix_dataset_new.py.
4. Define the rules as given in the rules.jpg screenshot.
5. Run the classifier-program to create a classification-model using: TestClassifier.py.
6. The output of step-4 is as follows:
```bash
(10, 6, 3)
weak_labels type:  <class 'argilla.labeling.text_classification.weak_labels.WeakMultiLabels'> label_model type:  <class 'argilla.labeling.text_classification.label_models.MajorityVoter'>
Empty DataFrame
Columns: []
Index: []
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "TestClassifier.py", line 50, in <module>
    train_df["label"] = train_df.prediction.map(multi_label_binarizer)
  File "C:\Anaconda3\envs\elasticsearch\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5907, in __getattr__
    return object.__getattribute__(self, name)
AttributeError: 'DataFrame' object has no attribute 'prediction'
```

**Expected behavior**
I was expecting to develop a classifier model, and output should have been the metrics of the model, as described in your sample ResearchTopics classifier code.

**Screenshots**
Program output has been already shared.  Attached please find the data-file and 3 python scripts.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: Windows
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Chrome
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.0.1
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: 8.4.3
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: not applicable

**Additional context**
Please let me know where I'm going wrong or if any other information is required.
[weak_test_classifier.xlsx](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/files/10285123/weak_test_classifier.xlsx)
[files.zip](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/files/10285147/files.zip)

title: fix: Resolve problems related to get reference record  in frontend
body:
# Description

This PR contains the first version of a full similarity search workflow. As technical comments I can say:

- The main vector info integration occurs in pages/datasets/_workspace/_dataset/index.vue
- The fetch method on this file does:
   1. ORM Data cleaning before fetching the data (`fetch` method)
   2. Read query params and setup the corresponding info (`fetch` method)
- The model `RefRecord` contains the record `task` type, in order to generate and propagate a proper record object to other components.

@keithCuniah @leiyre Not sure if is the proper target branch or if we should change the PR to the main branch for this feature. You can apply your criterium in that way

Refs #1757

title: feat: 1914 Allow to launch the argilla server in a different base_url
body:
# Description

This PR allows specifying a different base URL for the argilla server execution. This can be helpful when the argilla server is running behind a proxy.

Launch argilla as follows:
```bash
ARGILLA_BASE_URL=/this-is-argilla python -m argilla
```
to launch the argilla server in `http://localhost:6900/this-is-argilla`

Closes #1914

title: chore(deps-dev): update wrapt requirement from ~=1.13.0 to >=1.13,<1.15

labels.name: type: dependencies
labels.description: Indicates a pull request that updates a dependency file

body:
Updates the requirements on [wrapt](https://github.com/GrahamDumpleton/wrapt) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from wrapt's changelog.

Version 1.14.1

Bugs Fixed

  • When the post import hooks mechanism was being used, and a Python package with its own custom module importer was used, importing modules could fail if the custom module importer didn't use the latest Python import hook finder/loader APIs and instead used the deprecated API. This was actually occurring with the zipimporter in Python itself, which was not updated to use the newer Python APIs until Python 3.10.

Version 1.14.0

Bugs Fixed

  • Python 3.11 dropped inspect.formatargspec() which was used in creating signature changing decorators. Now bundling a version of this function which uses Parameter and Signature from inspect module when available. The replacement function is exposed as wrapt.formatargspec() if need it for your own code.

  • When using a decorator on a class, isinstance() checks wouldn't previously work as expected and you had to manually use Type.__wrapped__ to access the real type when doing instance checks. The __instancecheck__ hook is now implemented such that you don't have to use Type.__wrapped__ instead of Type as last argument to isinstance().

  • Eliminated deprecation warnings related to Python module import system, which would have turned into broken code in Python 3.12. This was used by the post import hook mechanism.

New Features

  • Binary wheels provided on PyPi for aarch64 Linux systems and macOS native silicon where supported by Python when using pypa/cibuildwheel.

Version 1.13.3

New Features

  • Adds wheels for Python 3.10 on PyPi and where possible also now generating binary wheels for musllinux.

Version 1.13.2

Features Changed

labels.name: type: dependencies
labels.description: Indicates a pull request that updates a dependency file

body:
Updates the requirements on [httpx](https://github.com/encode/httpx) to permit the latest version.
Release notes

Sourced from httpx's releases.

Version 0.23.1

0.23.1

Added

  • Support for Python 3.11. (#2420)
  • Allow setting an explicit multipart boundary in Content-Type header. (#2278)
  • Allow tuple or list for multipart values, not just list. (#2355)
  • Allow str content for multipart upload files. (#2400)
  • Support connection upgrades. See https://www.encode.io/httpcore/extensions/#upgrade-requests

Fixed

  • Don't drop empty query parameters. (#2354)

Removed

  • Drop .read/.aread from SyncByteStream/AsyncByteStream (#2407)
  • Drop RawURL. (#2241)
Changelog

Sourced from httpx's changelog.

0.23.1

Note: The 0.23.1 release should have used a proper version bump, rather than a minor point release. There are API surface area changes that may affect some users. See the "Removed" section of these release notes for details.

Added

  • Support for Python 3.11. (#2420)
  • Allow setting an explicit multipart boundary in Content-Type header. (#2278)
  • Allow tuple or list for multipart values, not just list. (#2355)
  • Allow str content for multipart upload files. (#2400)
  • Support connection upgrades. See https://www.encode.io/httpcore/extensions/#upgrade-requests

Fixed

  • Don't drop empty query parameters. (#2354)

Removed

  • Upload files must always be opened in binary mode. (#2400)
  • Drop .read/.aread from SyncByteStream/AsyncByteStream. (#2407)
  • Drop RawURL. (#2241)

0.23.0 (23rd May, 2022)

Changed

  • Drop support for Python 3.6. (#2097)
  • Use utf-8 as the default character set, instead of falling back to charset-normalizer for auto-detection. To enable automatic character set detection, see the documentation. (#2165)

Fixed

  • Fix URL.copy_with for some oddly formed URL cases. (#2185)
  • Digest authentication should use case-insensitive comparison for determining which algorithm is being used. (#2204)
  • Fix console markup escaping in command line client. (#1866)
  • When files are used in multipart upload, ensure we always seek to the start of the file. (#2065)
  • Ensure that iter_bytes never yields zero-length chunks. (#2068)
  • Preserve Authorization header for redirects that are to the same origin, but are an http-to-https upgrade. (#2074)
  • When responses have binary output, don't print the output to the console in the command line client. Use output like <16086 bytes of binary data> instead. (#2076)
  • Fix display of --proxies argument in the command line client help. (#2125)
  • Close responses when task cancellations occur during stream reading. (#2156)
  • Fix type error on accessing .request on HTTPError exceptions. (#2158)

0.22.0 (26th January, 2022)

Added

  • Support for the SOCKS5 proxy protocol via the socksio package. (#2034)
  • Support for custom headers in multipart/form-data requests (#1936)

title: Allow passing workspace as client parm for `rg.log` or `rg.load`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The current python client works using a workspace that can be changed with `rg.set_workspace` function. Sometimes and for MLOps purposes, the workspace could change frequently. For those cases, the `rg.set_workspace` becomes unsafer.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Passing the workspace as an optional argument at least for the 2 main functions could help to create safer workflows:

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.log(records, name, workspace="ws1")
rg.load(name, workspace="ws2")
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

The current solution for looks as follow:
```python
import argilla as rg

rg.set_workspace("ws1")
rg.log(records, name)

rg.set_workspace("ws2")
rg.load(name)

```

**Additional context**
N/A

body:
Updates the requirements on [psutil](https://github.com/giampaolo/psutil) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from psutil's changelog.

5.9.4

2022-11-07

Enhancements

  • 2102_: use Limited API when building wheels with CPython 3.6+ on Linux, macOS and Windows. This allows to use pre-built wheels in all future versions of cPython 3. (patch by Matthieu Darbois)

Bug fixes

  • 2077_, [Windows]: Use system-level values for virtual_memory()_. (patch by Daniel Widdis)
  • 2156_, [Linux]: compilation may fail on very old gcc compilers due to missing SPEED_UNKNOWN definition. (patch by Amir Rossert)
  • 2010_, [macOS]: on MacOS, arm64 IFM_1000_TX and IFM_1000_T are the same value, causing a build failure. (patch by Lawrence D'Anna)

5.9.3

2022-10-18

Enhancements

  • 2040_, [macOS]: provide wheels for arm64 architecture. (patch by Matthieu Darbois)

Bug fixes

  • 2116_, [macOS], [critical]: psutil.net_connections_ fails with RuntimeError.
  • 2135_, [macOS]: Process.environ()_ may contain garbage data. Fix out-of-bounds read around sysctl_procargs. (patch by Bernhard Urban-Forster)
  • 2138_, [Linux], [critical]: can't compile psutil on Android due to undefined ethtool_cmd_speed symbol.
  • 2142_, [POSIX]: net_if_stats()_ 's flags on Python 2 returned unicode instead of str. (patch by Matthieu Darbois)
  • 2147_, [macOS] Fix disk usage report on macOS 12+. (patch by Matthieu Darbois)
  • 2150_, [Linux] Process.threads()_ may raise NoSuchProcess. Fix race condition. (patch by Daniel Li)
  • 2153_, [macOS] Fix race condition in test_posix.TestProcess.test_cmdline. (patch by Matthieu Darbois)

5.9.2

2022-09-04

Release notes

Sourced from luqum's releases.

0.12.0

Changed

  • Boost can be implicit ; by default, the boost factor is 1

Added

  • Add support for Lucene and Elasticsearch Boolean operations (#71, thanks to @​linefeedse):

    • Introduce the BooleanOperation
    • add its resolution in ElasticSearch transformer
    • add it as a possible resolver for the unknown operation (no explicit operator in query)

  • Set E element as ElasticsearchQueryBuilder's attributes (#75, thanks to @​qcoumes):

    This allows to override elements such as EMust, EWord, ...,

title: feat(API): get record by id endpoints
body:
# Description

For now, the only way to fetch a single record content y by using the `:search` endpoint passing a list of `ids` in the query body, which can be counterintuitive for users.

This PR includes an additional API endpoint to retrieve a single record's content by id.

`GET /api/datasets/{task}/records/{id}`

This endpoint will be used for the future, and more specifically, for the new similarity search feature, to easily retrieve the info for the record reference selected for the similarity.

**Type of change**

Please delete options that are not relevant.

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Create a functional test running a find-by-id request with not found results (For all task types)

Not needed for other tasks since the endpoint is common to all of them.

title: [Similarity search] Add documentation guides
[Similarity search] Align weak label methods to the new vector storage feature (See the `extend_matrix` method)
body:
Currently, the [`WeakLabels.extend_matrix`](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/reference/python/python_labeling.html?highlight=extend_labels#argilla.labeling.text_classification.weak_labels.WeakLabels.extend_matrix) uses a set of embeddings to extend labels from defined rules using a similarity approach based on [`Epoxy`](https://github.com/HazyResearch/epoxy) 

Since argilla records now support embedding info in the `vectors` field,  a more accurate way should be using those vectors (when defined) to extend the weak labeling matrix. 

For example, having two vectors per record: `v1` and `v2`, this method could extend the matrix by using one of the vectors:

```python
weak_labels = WeakLabels(dataset="my_dataset")

weak_labels.extend_matrix([0.6]*len(weak_labels.rules), using_vector="v1")
```

title: too verbose failure logging during failed `rg.log()` (with too large chunk_size)

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Describe the bug**
The terminal gets bombarded with the complete records after failed logging attempts. When logging a lot of records or larger records, this is problematic because it freezes the IDE and doesn´t really stop.

Also the `rg.log` generally failed a lot with larger chunk_sizes, however, instead of failing so easily, I would initially expect this to just influence speed and only fail after a relatively large timeout (60s?).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to Any arbitrary large dataset with larger records for example `news-fakenews`within our pre-release.
2. upload data via `rg.log()`with a chunk size larger than 100
3. it starts failing after a while

**Expected behavior**
I would expect to get a message `# records with IDs x,y,z have failed` to process. Or a response item that contains the failed / processed record info.

**Screenshots**
N.A.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: iOS
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Firefox
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.1.1.
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:7.10.2
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: 1.1.1

**Additional context**
Not the finicky failure behaviour of the logging with larger chunk sizes.

feat: built-in latest versioning checks to provide warning about relevant updates and breaking changes

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We found a bug which is prevalent and not resolvable by updating, so we want to notify the user proactively about this. Additionally, package versions lead to mismatches in usage, and introduce relevant fixes and updates or breaking changes. Ideally, users should read this in the changelogs, but this isn´t done as much as we would like. Could we add a check to the `rg.init()` and `uvicorn.run()`to warn the user about this? 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like to see the following checks.
- [ ] Latest server version running
- [ ] Latest client version running
- [ ] Client connected to latest server version

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Adding this to the changelogs and sending a message on Slack, but this will not nearly cover all users.

**Additional context**
Streamlit has a functionality similar to this that notifies the user about using an outdated version of their package.
https://docs.streamlit.io/library/changelog
